Chapter 3, Section 7: Distinguishing the Differences. What is the difference between conditions and causes?
Some say:

The difference lies in whether they are universal or non-universal conditions. The first four are subsumed by the two conditions, because the six causes are included. The second and third are not subsumed by the causes, therefore they are known to be different in meaning from the other two. Because the meaning of conditions is the same, and because they are all different from causes.

There is a general distinction between causes and conditions, saying that causes are what gives rise, and conditions are what nurtures and grows, like the difference between the two mothers who give birth and raise.
Moreover, conditions assist causes so that they can give rise, and after arising, they continue in succession. The power of conditions nurtures and grows.
Some say:
Causes are only one, while conditions are many, like the differences between seeds, manure, and soil.
Moreover, the cause is not common, while the condition is common, like the eye and form.
Moreover, that which performs its own function is called a cause, while that which performs the function of another is called a condition, like a seed and manure.
Moreover, that which can give rise to is called a cause, while that which can support is called a condition, like a flower and a ribbon.
Moreover, the proximate is called a cause, while the distant is called a condition, like a pearl and the sun.
Moreover, the cause is that which gives birth, while the condition is that which accomplishes, like curds giving rise to ghee, and a person churning with an implement accomplishing it.

Moreover, that which has a direct meaning is called a cause, while that which can assist and manifest is called a condition, like the syllables and the syllables' conditions.ğŸ”½There are many such distinctions in meaning, therefore cause and condition are established as separate names and concepts.
The general meaning shows that the cause is close and the condition is distant, therefore the close and distant are frequently mentioned in the causes and conditions.
In accordance with principle and teaching, the various conditions have been briefly explained.ğŸ”½How do these conditions manifest the arising and ceasing of dharmas as their function?
It should be said for which stage of dharmas do the conditions function?
The verse states:
The two causes function at the time of cessation, the three causes function at the time of arising,
The other two causes function in opposition to the conditions.
The treatise states:

The previously mentioned five causes are the nature of causes and conditions. The two causes function at the time of cessation. The phrase at the time of cessation refers to dharmas in the present. Because cessation is present, it is called at the time of cessation.
The two causes of co-existence and association function at the stage of the present cessation of dharmas.
The two causes function at this stage, referring to those born together. If either is lacking, the function is completely absent. They cannot take objects in the present stage.
Thus, although these two causes simultaneously take effects and give effects at the same time, now they are only about the power to give effects.
The so-called three causes at the time of arising refer to future dharmas. At the stage of arising, arising is present, so it is called at the time of arising.
The three kinds of dharmas, similar, universal, and retributive, perform their functions in the present, and for this reason it is said that
the two kinds of results, similar and retributive, are attracted by the power of the cause and are caused to arise.
Similar and universal results may arise without an interval, and it can be said that when the result is in the present, the cause performs its function.
The cause and result of retribution are separated by a long period of time. The cause has long since perished and the result is just now arising. How can the function exist when the result is born?

It is not possible for the past to have a function. The word â€œfunctionâ€ here indicates power, and the difference between the two has already been discussed in the chapter on the two characteristics.
Even though the cause has perished and a long time has passed, it has the power to cause its result to arise, because it is unique.

Even though the function does not exist when the result is born, it is given the name function in regard to the power of the result. Only the power of the result is the true function, and the rest are called functions only figuratively.

The two conditions of cause and condition as direct antecedent have been discussed above in terms of their functions at two times. The two conditions of homogeneous immediately antecedent and condition as object have functions that are the opposite of these.
The condition as direct antecedent functions at the time a dharma is born, because when it is born, the prior mind and mental activities are attracted and opened up.

The condition as object functions at the time the condition is destroyed, because mind and mental activities must take objects in the present. The dominant condition is unobstructed as to the time of the arising and cessation of dharmas, and therefore its function is not restricted to any one time.

Now we must consider the following question: If the two conditions of coexistent and associated, and the condition as object function after the dharma is born, why establish these two causes and one condition?
If it is held that a cause must have a function in order to be established as a cause condition, then in the future world there would be no cause conditions.
However, this is not a problem for our school, which maintains that cause conditions exist in the future.
If this is so, why is it said that they have a function?
If the present state of cessation were to lack these two causes and one condition, then the dharmas that are being attracted into cessation would lack the function of grasping an object.
If the function of grasping an object is absent and it is still called a condition, then the final mind of an arhat would also be able to be established as an immediately antecedent condition.
This criticism is unreasonable, because it has already been explained.

It has been explained that the object-condition is not necessarily established by the presence of a function. What is the connection that would lead one to cite the immediately antecedent condition as an example?

That condition is necessarily established by the opening up and attraction of the mind, and therefore it is only in the present that it can be properly established. In the future, that condition definitely does not exist. Since it has had a function in the present, it can also be established in the past.
The object-condition is not only in the present. As long as it has a nature that exists, it can all be established as a condition. It is not necessarily established by the presence of a function.
Only in a small part and in a small way is the function of a condition obtained, not in all cases.
How do we know that only when it has a nature that exists can it be established as a condition?
Because if the substance of the object does not exist, consciousness does not arise.
If the condition as object has a function, then the subsequent unconditioned dharma should have a prior effect.

Or, this function is not established on the basis of directly producing effects, but rather is said to be the function on which dharmas rely in arising. Therefore, subsequent unconditioned dharmas have no prior effect.
What dharmas are produced by how many conditions?

The remaining dharmas arise from two conditions, not from the next moment, etc.
Commentary:
Here, the word by is used to indicate the meaning of cause. Mind and mental factors arise from four conditions.

As for the condition as object, except for producing mind, etc., it has no separate function. The six consciousnesses and their associated dharmas, according to their respective cases, take the five such as form and all dharmas as the condition as object.

The five causes are complete in the conditions of mind, etc. The preceding homogeneous class makes way for and induces the subsequent homogeneous class. This is called the condition as direct antecedent of mind, etc.
This dominant condition is all dharmas, each excluding its own nature, according to its own case.

It is not that at the time of the arising of those dharmas they exist.
How is it that mind, etc., arise from the four conditions?
How is it that the condition as cause has the nature of the five causes?

Even though the function of a dharma is established only at the time of its cessation, still it is not without efficacy at the time of its arising, because that dharma definitely will not arise apart from this efficacy. This is because mind and its activities necessarily depend on their objects and the two causes in order to be born.
If a dharma is the condition as object for another dharma, or is a cause for it, it is never for a short time. This is not the case in the Abhidharma.

The dominant condition is as explained above.

But because it is not produced by the exertion of mind, etc., it is omitted here and not mentioned.
Or this attainment of non-perception is only manifested by sound, not established in opposition to the two samÄdhis like the other.
Why are the two samÄdhis the condition as direct antecedent of mind, etc., but not said to be the condition as direct antecedent of mind, etc.?

Because they are produced by the power of mind, etc., because they necessarily depend on the cessation of the previous mind like mind and mental factors, because they cannot occur simultaneously with other minds like form dharmas, because they cannot appear together in a confused way like attainment, etc., and because they are not companions of others like birth, etc.

If the previous moment attracts the later one, then the last one should have no result.
It cannot be said that this samÄdhi attracts the mind that emerges from it, because it has already been said that it is opposed to mind and is not a condition as object of mind.

Because there is an interruption in the middle of the similar and immediately antecedent condition.

The meanings of uninterrupted and similar and immediately antecedent are different. The power of the previous mind attracts the arising of the subsequent dharma. The subsequent dharma is called the similar and immediately antecedent of the previous. Without an interval in a moment, it is called uninterrupted. Therefore, the two terms have different meanings. Thus it is said.
If a dharma is the similar and immediately antecedent condition for mind, is that dharma also the immediately antecedent condition for mind?

The remaining non-associated phenomena and all material phenomena are produced by both the causal and dominant conditions.
How do we know that all worldly phenomena are only produced by the above causes and conditions, and not produced by a single cause such as the Almighty, the Self, or the Primordial Nature?

Because of sequence. If all worldly phenomena were produced by a single cause such as the Almighty, they would all be produced simultaneously, not arising in sequence, because the cause would be present.
What dharma is the obstruction that prevents them from being produced simultaneously?
It is seen that phenomena arise in sequence, therefore we know they are not produced by a single cause.
If you insist that the world is not produced all at once because there are differences in the desires of God,

A result does not have differences when the cause is not different. It is only when a different cause is present that the result is different.
Or, because of differences, you must admit that it is produced all at once, because the cause that exists previously and subsequently is not different.
Then all dharmas would also be produced all at once. What can obstruct them so that they are not produced all at once?

They are causes and conditions for each other, from the point of view of self and other.

Immediately after the obscured [mind], seven minds can arise, namely the three of its own realm, the wholesome [mind] of the form realm, and the defiled [minds] of the desire and form realms.

Having explained the mutual generation of the twelve minds,
how are they divided into twenty minds?
Verse:
The twelve are divided into twenty, namely the wholesome minds of the three realms,
divided into acquired through practice and innate,
the minds of karmic retribution, deportment, craftsmanship, and spiritual powers,
in the form realm, excluding craftsmanship, the rest are as previously explained.
Treatise:
The wholesome minds of the three realms are each divided into two kinds, namely acquired through practice and innate, due to the difference.
The unrestrained minds of the desire realm are divided into four kinds: one, born of karmic retribution; two, deportment; three, craftsmanship; four, spiritual powers.
The unrestrained minds of the form realm are divided into three kinds, excluding craftsmanship, because the upper realms are completely devoid of the creation of various crafts;
because the formless realm is devoid of activities such as walking, etc., it has no deportment;
because it lacks the branches of embracing concentration, it also lacks spiritual powers.
On the basis of this principle, there are eight in the realm of desire, six in the realm of form, four in the realm of no form, and learner and post-learner minds, making twenty in all.

As for the mutual generation of these twenty minds, the good mind acquired through cultivation immediately after the good mind acquired through cultivation in the realm of desire generates ten minds, i.e., seven of its own realm, excluding the mind resulting from retribution and the good mind acquired at birth, because it is generated immediately after its own class of meditative states, and one in the realm of form, i.e., the good mind acquired through cultivation, and also the learner and post-learner minds.

This mind, in turn, is generated immediately after eight minds, i.e., four of its own realm, two good minds and two defiled minds, and two in the realm of form, i.e., the good mind acquired through cultivation and the defiled mind with false views.

The good mind acquired at birth immediately after the good mind acquired through cultivation generates nine minds, i.e., seven of its own realm, excluding the mind resulting from retribution and the good mind acquired through cultivation, and the defiled minds of the realm of form and the formless realm.

This mind, in turn, is generated immediately after eleven minds, i.e., seven of its own realm, excluding the mind resulting from retribution, and two in the realm of form, i.e., the good mind acquired through cultivation and the defiled mind with false views,
and the learner and post-learner minds.
Two defiled minds immediately follow seven minds, excluding the mind obtained from retribution and the mind of the stage of post-attainment.

These two defiled minds immediately follow fourteen minds, namely, the seven of its own stage, excluding the mind obtained from retribution and the mind of the stage of post-attainment; the four of the form realm, excluding the wholesome acquired through application and the mind of the stage of post-attainment; and the three of the formless realm, excluding the wholesome acquired through application.

The mind obtained from retribution and the mind of deportment immediately follow eight minds, namely, the six of its own stage, excluding the wholesome acquired through application and the mind of the stage of post-attainment; and the obscured-neutral minds of the form and formless realms.
These two minds immediately follow seven minds, namely, the seven of its own stage, excluding the mind of the stage of post-attainment.

The mind of skill in arts and crafts immediately follows six minds, namely, the six of its own stage, excluding the wholesome acquired through application and the mind of the stage of post-attainment.

This mind immediately follows two minds, namely, the two minds of its own and the form realms, as explained above.

Next, it is explained that from the mind of wholesome practice in the six types of minds in the form realm, twelve arise immediately, namely the six of its own realm, the three wholesome, born of retribution, and fruition minds of the desire realm, and the wholesome practice mind of the formless realm, and the learner and post-learner minds.

This [wholesome practice mind] in turn arises immediately after ten [minds], namely the four of its own realm, excluding the mind of deportment and the mind born of retribution, and the two wholesome practice and fruition minds of the desire realm, and the two wholesome practice and obscured minds of the formless realm, and the learner and post-learner minds.

The wholesome mind born of retribution immediately gives rise to eight [minds], namely the five of its own realm, excluding the fruition mind, and the two unwholesome and obscured minds of the desire realm, and the obscured indeterminate mind of the form realm.
This [wholesome mind born of retribution] in turn arises immediately after five [minds], namely the five of its own realm, excluding the fruition mind.

The obscured indeterminate mind immediately gives rise to nine [minds], namely the five of its own realm, excluding the fruition mind, and the four of the desire realm, two wholesome and two defiled [minds].

The mind obtained from retribution and the mind of deportment immediately give rise to seven minds, namely, four of its own realm excluding the wholesome mind acquired by practice and the mind obtained from retribution through cultivation, and the two defiled minds of the desire realm, and one defiled mind of the formless realm.
This mind, in turn, arises immediately after five minds, namely, the five of its own realm excluding the mind obtained from retribution through cultivation.

Immediately after the mind obtained from retribution through cultivation, two minds arise, namely, the two of its own realmâ€”the wholesome mind acquired by practice and the mind obtained from retribution through cultivation.
This mind, in turn, arises immediately after two minds, namely, the two minds of its own realm as just mentioned.
Having explained the mutual arising of minds in the form realm,

next, the four kinds of minds in the formless realm are discussed. The wholesome mind acquired by practice immediately gives rise to seven minds, namely, the four of its own realm, the wholesome mind acquired by practice of the form realm, and the learner and post-learner minds.
Further, it is immediately followed by six, namely, three of its own realm excluding the fruition consciousness, and the good mind acquired by training of the realm of form, and the two pure minds.
The good mind acquired by birth is immediately followed by seven, namely, four of its own realm, and the obscured-neutral mind of the realm of form, and the two defiled minds of the realm of desire.
Further, it is immediately followed by four, namely, the four of its own realm.

The obscured-neutral mind is immediately followed by eight, namely, four of its own realm, and the two good and the obscured-neutral minds of the realm of form, and the two defiled minds of the realm of desire.

Further, it is immediately followed by ten, namely, the four of its own realm, and the three of the realm of form, namely, the mind as retribution, the good mind acquired by birth, and the mind associated with deportment. The names are as explained in the realm of form.

The mind as retribution is immediately followed by six, namely, three of its own realm, excluding the good mind acquired by effort, and the obscured-neutral mind of the realm of form, and the two defiled minds of the realm of desire.
Furthermore, it arises from four, which are the four of its own realm.
Having explained the arising of formless realm minds from each other,

next, from a mind of the two kinds of pure training, six arise immediately, namely, the wholesome of added effort of the three realms, the innate of the desire realm, and the minds of training and no-training.
Furthermore, it arises from four immediately, namely, the three of added effort and the mind of training.
From a mind of no-training, five arise immediately, namely, five out of the six that arise from the mind of training, excluding the mind of training.
Furthermore, it arises from five immediately, namely, the three of added effort, and the minds of training and no-training.
What is the reason that added effort can immediately give rise to the karmic maturation, craftsmanship, and deportment?

There is no contradiction in the mind of good acquired through application immediately following the two mindless samÄdhis.

There is no contradiction in the mind of good acquired through application immediately following the two mindless samÄdhis.
If this is so, then the mind of good acquired through application should not be immediately followed by a defiled mind, because attachment to an object is contrary to goodness.
There is no such fault, because the mind of good acquired through application is weak in power. One becomes weary of the passions and frequently brings to mind the thought,
What expedient can I use to stop the occurrence of this evil?

Then, knowing the object that produces faults as really able to produce merit, one is freed from the arising of afflictions in the present, and one is able to perceive and protect against their arising.
By the power of this vow, one is able to arouse effort.

But because it is not drawn out by superior effort, one cannot arouse those minds from this [innate good]. Because the innate good minds of the form and formless realms are not clear and sharp, and because they are not drawn out by superior effort,
one cannot arouse the good and uncontaminated minds of other realms immediately after them, nor can one arouse those minds from this [innate good].
Moreover, because the innate good of the desire realm is clear and sharp, one can arouse it immediately after the defilements of the form realm, and it can serve as a protection.

There are three kinds of attention: attention to specific characteristics, attention to general characteristics, and attention to resolve.
What is attention to specific characteristics?
It refers to attention associated with the observation of the characteristics of various forms as obstruction, up to the observation of consciousness as cognition.
What is attention to general characteristics?
It refers to attention associated with the sixteen aspects.
What is attention to resolve?
It refers to attention associated with the observation of impurity, the four immeasurables, the formless liberations, the spheres of mastery, and the spheres of totality.
These three kinds of attention immediately precede the manifestation of the holy path, and the holy path is also able to give rise to all three kinds of attention immediately.
If this is said, it accords with this statement:
Cultivating the factors of enlightenment such as mindfulness associated with the practice of impurity meditation.
Other masters say:
Only the holy path is manifested immediately after the attention of the common characteristics, and only after the holy path can one generate the three kinds of attention.
If this is so, why does a scripture say,
â€œThe various members of enlightenment such as mindfulness are cultivated in conjunction with the contemplation of impurity?â€

Because the mind is subdued by the contemplation of impurity, one is then able to attract the attention of the common characteristics, and the holy path is manifested immediately after this attention.
This is said with an indirect intention and is not erroneous.
There is another opinion that
only the holy path is manifested immediately after the attention of the common characteristics, and only after the holy path can one generate the attention of the common characteristics.
This statement is erroneous.
Why is this?

When one enters the state of being bound to attain nirvana in the three stages of the preliminary stage of the stage of neither conception nor nonconception, the holy path is manifested immediately after the attention of the common characteristics of the realm of desire, because the attention of the common characteristics of the realm of desire is not too far removed from that holy path.
If one enters the state of certainty of attaining Arhatship by relying on the second, third, or fourth trance state, what kind of thought is produced immediately after the holy path?
One does not produce the thought of the general characteristics of the realm of desire, because it is too far removed, and also because it is impossible to have it in that stage.

It is not the case that one has already obtained the thought of the general characteristics in that stage, because it is different from the thought of the general characteristics that conforms to the state of discernment of the truths, which one has already obtained.

It is not the case that the state of discernment of the truths that conforms to the holy path can appear again, because it is impossible for one who has already obtained the fruit to generate again the path of added effort.
They must now explain what kind of thought of the general characteristics appears immediately after the holy path.

Is it not the case that it is related to the state of discernment of the truths that conforms to the holy path, and also cultivates that kind of thought of the general characteristics, just as one contemplates all conditioned dharmas as impermanent, all dharmas as without self, and nirvana as tranquil? The holy path immediately induces it to appear.

This refutation is unreasonable, because the thought of the general characteristics that is cultivated by the related path of added effort cannot be induced to appear after one has obtained the fruit, because it is of that kind.
The previous explanation that the three kinds of attention appear immediately after the noble path is reasonable.
If one attains the fruit of arhatship based on the preliminary concentration, the mind that emerges from contemplation is either of that stage or of the desire realm.
If one attains the fruit of arhatship based on the sphere of nothingness, the mind that emerges from contemplation is either of that stage or of the peak of existence.
If one attains the fruit of arhatship based on other stages, the mind that emerges from contemplation is only of that stage, not of other stages.
In the desire realm there are three kinds of attention: that which is acquired by hearing, that which is acquired by thinking, and that which is acquired by birth.
The form realm also has three kinds of attention: that which is acquired by hearing;
that which is acquired by cultivation;
and that which is acquired by birth. There is none acquired by thinking, because when one raises the thought to contemplate, one immediately enters concentration.
The formless realm has only two kinds of attention: that which is acquired by cultivation and that which is acquired by birth.

When the holy path is present, the three kinds of attention are present, because the arising of the holy path is necessarily related to the path of added effort. The attention of acquired good is not present immediately after the holy path.
When the holy path is present, the two kinds of attention of the realm of form are present, and when the holy path is present, the two kinds of attention are also present.

When the holy path is present, the attention of cultivation of the formless realm is present, and when the holy path is present, only the attention of cultivation is present, and that of birth is absent.

When one who has been born in the second trance state or above produces the three kinds of sense consciousness of the first trance state, those who have not yet eliminated the passions of their stage have the three kinds of sense consciousness present immediately after the good, impure, and indeterminate attention of their stage, and the three kinds of sense consciousness are born immediately after the three kinds of attention of their stage.

When one has already separated from the passions of a certain stage, except for the attention of passion, only the wholesome and indeterminate attentions are immediately followed by the three kinds of consciousness. The three kinds of consciousness are also immediately followed by only these two kinds of attention.
In the twelve minds that have been discussed above, which minds are present?
How many minds can be obtained?
Verse:
The defiled minds of the three realms obtain seven, six, and two kinds in order.
The wholesome minds of the form realm obtain two, and the two learners obtain three. The two formless realms obtain by themselves.
Verse:
In the state when a defiled mind of the desire realm is present, seven minds are obtained among the twelve minds.
In the state when a defiled mind of the form realm is present, six minds are obtained among the twelve minds.
In the state when a defiled mind of the formless realm is present, two minds are obtained among the twelve minds.
Are they obtained in one moment?

It should be said that this is not so. When a defiled mind of the desire realm arises, either one returns from the realm or one continues the root of good or one falls away from superior qualities. In these three situations, one obtains a number of minds as appropriate.

When one returns from the realm, one obtains the four of one's own realm and also the defiled mind of the form realm. It is also possible to obtain the wholesome mind of one's own realm in the situation of continuing the root of good, because one continues the root of good in a state of doubt.
In the situation of falling away from superior qualities, it is possible to obtain the defiled minds of the three realms and the mind of one still learning.
When a defiled mind of the form realm arises, either one returns from the realm or one falls away from superior qualities. One obtains a number of minds as appropriate.
When one returns from the realm, one obtains the three kinds of one's own realm, and also obtains the unobscured-neutral mind of the desire realm, namely the mind of spiritual powers.
In the situation of falling away from superior qualities, it is possible to obtain the two defiled minds of the form and formless realms and the mind of one still learning.
When a defiled mind of the formless realm arises, one suddenly obtains two minds, namely the mind of one still learning and one's own defiled mind.
Here there is only the state of falling away from superior virtues.
When a wholesome mind of the form realm is presently manifest, two minds are obtained from among the twelve minds, namely its own wholesome mind and unobscured-indeterminate mind, due to advancement.

When a mind of the learner stage is presently manifest, three minds are obtained from among the twelve minds, namely the mind of the learner stage, and the unobscured-indeterminate of the form realm, and the wholesome mind of the formless realm.
If one first enters the certainty of perfection, at that time the mind of the learner stage is called obtained.
If one uses the noble path to detach from the defilements of the desire realm, at the time of the final liberated path, one obtains the unobscured-indeterminate of the form realm.
If one uses the noble path to detach from the defilements of the form realm, one obtains the wholesome mind of the formless realm.

Here, the term detach does not mean complete detachment, because when one has not completely detached from the defilements of the form realm, the wholesome mind of the formless realm can already be obtained.
The second refers to the unobscured-indeterminate of the desire realm and form realm. In these two minds, none are obtained at all.
The remaining refers to the defiled and other minds mentioned above.
The remaining [minds] refer to the non-obscuring indeterminate of the formless realm, the wholesome of the desire realm and formless realm, and the mind of the adept.

It is not said that when those minds are presently manifest, the distinctions of mind are obtained. One should know that when those minds are presently manifest, only their own [minds] can be obtained.
